page.title: 07CHURNET VALLEY WILDLIFE
page.content: Herons fly up the valley and fish in the river.Grey wagtail, kingfishers and dippers have re-appeared on the River Churnet which is now able to support fish and other wildlife after years of pollution. Redstarts,woodwarblers,flycatchers and sparrowhawks are among the rich variety of woodland birds.There are still hedge -row birds such as yellowhammer,linnets and goldfinch in good numbers. Buzzards have re-established themselves close-by Stoats,weasels,rabbits and other small mammals are plentiful and there are good numbers of badgers and foxes. Munchat deer have been seen. The remnants of deciduous woodland are very rich entomologically, maintaining an insect population of 200 years ago.A rare caddisfly breeds in Dimmingsdale. There are many records in the North Staffordshire Field Club Journal.
